statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Oklahoma 70, Tulsa 64
article.story: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- With its point guard limited by an injury, Oklahoma had to find different ways to score and Jaison Williams had just the touch the Sooners needed. Williams was 5-for-8 from 3-point range and scored a career-high 21 points as Oklahoma squandered a 14-point second-half lead but rallied to beat Tulsa 70-64 Tuesday night. "He was the one senior that came to play and really help this team win," Oklahoma coach Kelvin Sampson said. "Jaison was tough. He was our best player tonight." Anthony Price scored inside to cap a 20-5 run that gave Tulsa a 60-59 lead with 3 minutes to play. Lawrence McKenzie answered with a long 3-pointer from the right wing to give Oklahoma the lead for good and Price missed a pair of free throws on Tulsa's next possession to help the Sooners (8-2) build on their lead. Kevin Bookout put back a Taj Gray miss to make it 64-60 and answered a Jarius Glenn runner with a right-handed hook shot to maintain Oklahoma's lead. Williams hit four free throws in the final minute to preserve the lead. Oklahoma's only natural point guard, Drew Lavender, played only two minutes in the second half after injuring his right index finger in practice earlier in the week. Sampson said Lavender had his finger in a splint and couldn't extend it when he dribbled. "Our shot selection exactly wasn't what we wanted, but we had guys that weren't point guards in point guard situations and that contributed to it," Sampson said. Sampson said Lavender's injury would take about a week and a half to heal, but he was uncertain whether Lavender would be able to play during that time. Price finished with 19 points and Glenn had 16 points and nine rebounds as Tulsa (2-6) nearly gave Alvin Williamson a victorious head coaching debut. "There's a lot of work to be done between the ears," said Williamson, who took over after John Phillips resigned Saturday. "We don't play for moral victories at the University of Tulsa." Vernell Davis scored 12 points and Seneca Collins added 10 for Tulsa, which hasn't beaten Oklahoma since 1996. "Coach had us ready, but I think everybody wanted this game," Glenn said. "We wanted to show everybody we're going to be a quality basketball team by the time it's over." Bookout had 10 points and 13 rebounds for Oklahoma, which outrebounded Tulsa 33-28 and limited the Golden Hurricane to five offensive rebounds and four second-chance points. Terrell Everett added 15 points, McKenzie had 13 points and Gray scored 10 After a competitive first half, the Sooners pulled ahead with a 10-0 run in the final 1:39 as Williams and McKenzie hit back-to-back 3-pointers before Gray's two-handed slam made it 33-23. Brett McDade hit a driving layup just before halftime to pull Tulsa within eight. Williams hit a 3-pointer from the top of the key to make it 40-29 and Everett extended the lead to 54-40 with a steal and right-handed layup. Then Tulsa began to rally back. The Golden Hurricane scored 10 straight points and pulled within 56-54 when Davis slipped behind Bookout for a layup with just under 7 minutes to play. Price gave Tulsa its first lead of the second half with two free throws with 4:14 to play, but the Golden Hurricane couldn't hold on for its biggest win of the season. "Give Tulsa some credit," Sampson said. "That's one emotional ringer those kids have been through this week."
